column2: Fit the Third
column3: Fit the Third

column2: THE BAKER'S TALE
column3: THE BAKER'S TALE

column2: They roused him with muffins--they roused him with ice-- They roused him with mustard and cress-- They roused him with jam and judicious advice-- They set him conundrums to guess.
column3: They roused him with muffins-they roused him with ice- They roused him with mustard and cress- They roused him with jam and judicious advice- They set him conundrums to guess.

column2: When at length he sat up and was able to speak, His sad story he offered to tell; And the Bellman cried "Silence!
column3: When at length he sat up and was able to speak, His sad story he offered to tell; And the Bellman cried "Silence!

column2: Not even a shriek!" And excitedly tingled his bell.
column3: Not even a shriek!" And excitedly tingled his bell.

column2: There was silence supreme!
column3: There was silence supreme!

column2: Not a shriek, not a scream, Scarcely even a howl or a groan, As the man they called "Ho!" told his story of woe In an antediluvian tone.
column3: Not a shriek, not a scream, Scarcely even a howl or a groan, As the man they called "Ho!" told his story of woe In an antediluvian tone.

column2: My father and mother were honest, though poor-- "Skip all that!" cried the Bellman in haste. "If it once becomes dark, there's no chance of a Snark-- We have hardly a minute to waste!"
column3: My father and mother were honest, though poor- "Skip all that!" cried the Bellman in haste. "If it once becomes dark, there's no chance of a Snark- We have hardly a minute to waste!"

column2: I skip forty years, said the Baker, in tears, "And proceed without further remark To the day when you took me aboard of your ship To help you in hunting the Snark.
column3: I skip forty years, said the Baker, in tears, "And proceed without further remark To the day when you took me aboard of your ship To help you in hunting the Snark.

column2: A dear uncle of mine (after whom I was named) Remarked, when I bade him farewell-- "Oh, skip your dear uncle!" the Bellman exclaimed, As he angrily tingled his bell.
column3: A dear uncle of mine (after whom I was named) Remarked, when I bade him farewell- "Oh, skip your dear uncle!" the Bellman exclaimed, As he angrily tingled his bell.

column2: He remarked to me then, said that mildest of men, "'If your Snark be a Snark, that is right: Fetch it home by all means--you may serve it with greens, And it's handy for striking a light.
column3: He remarked to me then, said that mildest of men, "'If your Snark be a Snark, that is right: Fetch it home by all means-you may serve it with greens, And it's handy for striking a light.

column2: 'You may seek it with thimbles--and seek it with care; You may hunt it with forks and hope; You may threaten its life with a railway-share; You may charm it with smiles and soap--'
column3: 'You may seek it with thimbles-and seek it with care; You may hunt it with forks and hope; You may threaten its life with a railway share; You may charm it with smiles and soap-'

column2: ("That's exactly the method," the Bellman bold In a hasty parenthesis cried, "That's exactly the way I have always been told That the capture of Snarks should be tried!")
column3: ("That's exactly the method," the Bellman bold In a hasty parenthesis cried, "That's exactly the way I have always been told That the capture of Snarks should be tried!")

column2: 'But oh, beamish nephew, beware of the day, If your Snark be a Boojum!	'But oh, beamish nephew, beware of the day, If your Snark be a Boojum!

It is this, it is this that oppresses my soul, When I think of my uncle's last words: And my heart is like nothing so much as a bowl Brimming over with quivering curds!	It is this, it is this that oppresses my soul, When I think of my uncle's last words: And my heart is like nothing so much as a bowl Brimming over with quivering curds!
It is this, it is this--
column3: It is this, it is this-

column2: We have had that before! The Bellman indignantly said. And the Baker replied "Let me say it once more. It is this, it is this that I dread!
column3: We have had that before! The Bellman indignantly said. And the Baker replied "Let me say it once more. It is this, it is this that I dread!

column2: But if ever I meet with a Boojum, that day, In a moment (of this I am sure), I shall softly and suddenly vanish away-- And the notion I cannot endure!
column3: But if ever I meet with a Boojum, that day, In a moment (of this I am sure), I shall softly and suddenly vanish away- And the notion I cannot endure!

column2: Fit the fourth
column3: Fit the fourth

column2: The Bellman looked uffish, and wrinkled his brow. "If only you'd spoken before! It's excessively awkward to mention it now, With the Snark, so to speak, at the door!
column3: The Bellman looked uffish, and wrinkled his brow. "If only you'd spoken before! It's excessively awkward to mention it now, With the Snark, so to speak, at the door!

column2: It's excessively awkward to mention it now-- As I think I've already remarked. And the man they called "Hi!" replied, with a sigh, "I informed you the day we embarked.
column3: It's excessively awkward to mention it now- As I think I've already remarked. And the man they called "Hi!" replied, with a sigh, "I informed you the day we embarked.

column2: You may charge me with murder--or want of sense-- (We are all of us weak at times): But the slightest approach to a false pretence Was never among my crimes!	You may charge me with murder-or want of sense- (We are all of us weak at times): But the slightest approach to a false pretence Was never among my crimes!
I said it in Hebrew--I said it in Dutch-- I said it in German and Greek: But I wholly forgot (and it vexes me much) That English is what you speak!
column3: I said it in Hebrew-I said it in Dutch- I said it in German and Greek: But I wholly forgot (and it vexes me much) That English is what you speak!

column2: 'Tis a pitiful tale, said the Bellman, whose face Had grown longer at every word: "But, now that you've stated the whole of your case, More debate would be simply absurd.
column3: 'tis a pitiful tale, said the Bellman, whose face Had grown longer at every word: "But, now that you've stated the whole of your case, More debate would be simply absurd.

column2: To seek it with thimbles, to seek it with care; To pursue it with forks and hope; To threaten its life with a railway-share; To charm it with smiles and soap!	To seek it with thimbles, to seek it with care; To pursue it with forks and hope; To threaten its life with a railway share; To charm it with smiles and soap!

For the Snark's a peculiar creature, that won't Be caught in a commonplace way. Do all that you know, and try all that you don't: Not a chance must be wasted to-day!	For the Snark's a peculiar creature, that won't Be caught in a commonplace way. Do all that you know, and try all that you don't: Not a chance must be wasted to day!
For England expects--I forbear to proceed: 'Tis a maxim tremendous, but trite: And you'd best be unpacking the things that you need To rig yourselves out for the fight.
column3: For England expects-I forbear to proceed: 'tis a maxim tremendous, but trite: And you'd best be unpacking the things that you need To rig yourselves out for the fight.

column2: Then the Banker endorsed a blank cheque (which he crossed), And changed his loose silver for notes. The Baker with care combed his whiskers and hair, And shook the dust out of his coats.
column3: Then the Banker endorsed a blank cheque (which he crossed), And changed his loose silver for notes. The Baker with care combed his whiskers and hair, And shook the dust out of his coats.

column2: The Boots and the Broker were sharpening a spade-- Each working the grindstone in turn: But the Beaver went on making lace, and displayed No interest in the concern:
column3: The Boots and the Broker were sharpening a spade- Each working the grindstone in turn: But the Beaver went on making lace, and displayed No interest in the concern:

column2: The maker of Bonnets ferociously planned A novel arrangement of bows: While the Billiard-marker with quivering hand Was chalking the tip of his nose.
column3: The maker of Bonnets ferociously planned A novel arrangement of bows: While the Billiard marker with quivering hand Was chalking the tip of his nose.

column2: But the Butcher turned nervous, and dressed himself fine, With yellow kid gloves and a ruff-- Said he felt it exactly like going to dine, Which the Bellman declared was all "stuff."
column3: But the Butcher turned nervous, and dressed himself fine, With yellow kid gloves and a ruff- Said he felt it exactly like going to dine, Which the Bellman declared was all "stuff."
